title: L1 Visa worked 6 years - Can I apply Green Card?
question: I have heard that since 2010, person who'd have visa L1 and worked in USA 6 years can apply Green Card (My friend watched TV and let me know). It's that true? Please let me know. Thanks a lot !
question_tags: Immigration,Green cards,US visas,Immigrant status,Bankruptcy,Debt,Debt relief,Bankruptcy and debt,Employment,L-1B specialized knowledge visa
answers:
I will agree with my colleagues. It is totally unrelated. If you have an L1A, you do not need a labor certification to apply for a greencard. If it is an L1B, you need a labor certification. See attached links on the process and requirements:
http://www.peerallylaw.com/en/content/view/498
http://www.peerallylaw.com/en/content/view/499

Consult a good immigration lawyer who handles such cases. Our law firm do handle such cases

L-1A managers and executives may be petitioned for directly by their company in the EB-1 category for multinational managers and executives. L-1B specialized knowledge workers must go through the labor certification process before the company can file an I-140 petition for them. You should consult with an experienced immigration attorney to assess your options and devise an appropriate strategy for you.

Speak with a qualified immigration attorney concerning your options.

There is no connection between having worked on an L-1 for a certain period of time and eligibility to apply for a green card. You may well be eligible to apply for a green card, and depending on the nature of your job here and the overseas related entity before coming here as well as willingness of the employer to sponsor, you may well be eligible for a faster-track green card that is similar in nature to the requirements to an L-1A visa.

The proplem is that at six years in, you don't have very much time in the U.S. left.

So, speak with a lawyer to get real answers.
